As campaigners continue to oppose the planned expansion of Luton Airport, the local man who hopes to be the new MP here has written to the Minister of Aviation calling on the Government to halt plans to almost double the size of Luton airport.
The plans would see Luton Airport almost double in size from 18 million passengers a year to a whopping 32 million – the same size as Gatwick.
‘The people of Harpenden and our beautiful villages don’t want the equivalent of Gatwick Airport on their door-steps. We have to come together as a community and stop this,’ Nigel Gardner told local residents.
Aviation will be the single largest producer of carbon emissions by 2050, forecasts show. ‘How can we be serious about net zero if we double the size of Luton airport’ added Gardner, who grew up locally.
‘Luton is simply the wrong location for another giant airport.’
‘This expansion needs to be put on ice until we have a proper strategy for the reduction of aviation emissions’, Mr Gardner wrote.
‘I remember growing up in Flamstead and my parents complaining about the noise from the planes. That was long before Ryanair, Easyjet, TUI and Wizz Air. Now it’s far, far, worse.’
Harpenden Councillor Teresa Heritage said, ‘Luton airport already has a bad record enforcing planning conditions, with cargo flights and private jets taking off at all hours. The growth plans will make this so much worse for local residents.’
Campaigners are also worried by the increase in road traffic congestion. ‘Be it the M1 or the Lower Luton Road we just don’t have the capacity for more traffic’ added Gardner.

As we enter the final stages of the General Election campaign, Harpenden and Berkhamsted Conservative candidate Nigel Gardner has received two new endorsements.
The first is from Welwyn Hatfield MP and defence secretary Grant Shapps, who said: “I know first-hand that Nigel will be a true local champion…
“In a more volatile and dangerous world, Nigel understands how seriously you take our country’s security, and that’s why he backs our pledge to spend 2.5% of GDP on defence, amounting to billions of pounds in extra funding for our armed forces…”
David Gauke, who was Conservative MP for South West Herts from 2005-2019, and then as an independent MP until the end of that Parliament, has also pledged his support.
At the time his constituency included Berkhamsted, Tring and the surrounding villages.
He said: “If I lived in Harpenden and Berkhamsted, I have to say I’d be voting for Nigel Gardner.. Now I understand there are a lot of people who are disenchanted with the Conservative Party because I’m one of them.
“But in Harpenden and Berkhamsted you have got a candidate who will provide moderate, sensible, common sense Conservative values; will stand up to the extremes who want to take over the Conservative Party; and if there’s a Labour government, he’ll hold them to account in an effective way.”
Meanwhile, Lib Dem candidate Victoria Collins’ campaign has received a fresh boost from comedian and actor Steve Coogan, five years after he gave his endorsement to St Albans’ Daisy Cooper ahead of her election as MP.
So can lightning strike twice and he secure victory for the Lib Dems in Harpenden and Berkhamsted?
“I hope so. I just want to get the Tories out and the Lib Dem candidates generally have values that I adhere to but the principal message is to vote tactically.
“You know my loyalty shifts, I’ve got certain issues with Labour at the moment but generally I support them, but the most important thing is to get the Tories out in a decisive way and that means voting tactically, so in certain constituencies voting Lib Dem, and in others voting Labour. So that’s what I’m advising people to do.”
A recent poll on the General Election published by The Economist, predicts a slight Lib Dem victory in Harpenden and Berkhamsted with 30 per cent of the vote, Conservatives just below at 28 per cent, and Labour third at 20 per cent. But UK Polling Report puts the Conservatives in the lead with 26.8%, Labour second on 24.14%, and Lib Dems third on 22.5%, but admits the result is too close to call.

Come the general election Harpenden, Berkhamsted and Tring will form a new Parliamentary seat running across a whole swathe of Hertfordshire.
My family and I live in the new Hitchin seat, so I have made the decision to contest that seat at the election - and on Saturday I was delighted that Nigel Gardner has been selected as the Conservative candidate for the new Harpenden & Berkhamsted seat.

Unusually for a Friday afternoon, there is a big buzz of people gathered in The Oddfellows Arms in Harpenden’s Leyton Green, while outside a large security detail of men in suits and earpieces wait near their black Jeeps and monitor the situation.
It was upstairs at the pub that Conservative prospective Parliamentary candidate Nigel Gardner’s grandmother and her five sisters were born, so he said it seemed right that he should take his old university friend there for a pint when he was town.
Nigel and our current Foreign Secretary – and now Lord – David Cameron first met more than 30 years ago at Oxford University.
It followed what might be seen as an inauspicious first meeting. Nigel arrived at the prestigious hall of learning after catching a National Express coach from Luton.
“When I arrived I sat next to this young chap with bushy hair and said to him, ‘Where are you from?’ He said ‘Luton’, I heard Luton. I said I had just come on the National Express and I didn’t see him on the coach. ‘Did your parents bring you?’ He looked at me, and this time he said it very clearly, ‘Not Luton, Eton’. And that was David Cameron.”
Flash-forwards three decades, and Nigel is campaigning to win the new constituency of Harpenden and Berkhamsted for the Conservatives, while former Prime Minister and Tory party leader David has recently returned to government as Foreign Secretary.
Outside the pub there is quite the assembly. Apart from local Tory campaigners there are some Oxford students who have been following in David’s stead. There is a lot of blue. It’s all very Harpenden and you’d really never know right now that I was born in Salford.
All of a sudden David walks in. He gives a quick talk about how brilliant Nigel will be if he is elected as MP, all reassuring charm, calm voice, pragmatic clothing and jovial demeanour. I hear myself give a little whoop amid the clapping. Am I now a Tory?
David pulls a pint of Rebellion behind the bar – classic has-to-be-done part of any politician visits pub shenanigans. He tells a story about how when he met Chinese president Xi Jinping at The Plough in Cadsden, next to Chequers, the Chinese secret police said there was no way Xi was drinking a pint of Rebellion Beer, so they opted for a Greene King IPA instead.
We walk through the High Street, the sun is shining and a man stops to ask for a selfie with David outside Serena Hart. A foreign Big Issue vendor wishes us a good afternoon and another pub landlord invites him in for a pint which is politely declined with a “We may pop in on the way back!” Very diplomatic, but that sort of goes with the job.
Nigel and David visit Serena Hart where David compliments owner Mary Durkin on her dress, adding that his wife is a dressmaker. Hers is from M&S it turns out. They have a bit of a chat about parking issues and the worry there is locally about free parking being taken away by St Albans district council.
There’s a similar conversation at clothing boutique Oui a few doors, but I missed much of it when I was frogmarched outside by one of his team and quizzed on my motives for being there.
I told them I was a local journalist writing a colour piece on the visit, adding that “although I am NOT a Tory” they don’t need to be concerned. I’m still not sure what exactly they were worried I was going to report. Just justifying their jobs while they still have them, perhaps. Ooh scathing – oops I broke my promise!
I manage to have a proper – albeit short – chat with David in the offices of local housebuilders Jarvis. I ask him what Nigel was like back in their university days.
“He was very bright. He was quite bouncy. I remember that I was there for my interview and I think Nigel was the first person who came up and said hello. And we haven’t really looked back since then.
“He’s always been very outgoing, very intelligent, very hard-working. And these are all good qualities that you need as a Member of Parliament.”
It’s refreshing to hear a politician say something positive about another politician – you can’t always guarantee that will be the case, even when they’re from the same party!
I ask him why he thinks it is important to support small businesses and high streets like ours: “The high streets are such important parts of our community and they’re only going to survive if we help them. They’re under enormous pressure because of everyone shopping on Amazon and buying online and all the rest of it. And so we have to think what can we do to help have a varied, interesting high street.
“We can help by keeping free parking, we can help by making sure the planning authorities are creative and make sure they bring interesting people in, we can make sure have a bit of a decluttering of some of our roads and signs, which good local councils do.”
This is a big passion of Nigel’s campaign, to protect the high street, keep it local and keep parking accessible to all, and he’s obviously pleased to receive the thumbs-up from David.
So what is David personally most proud of the Conservatives achieving during the past 14 years in government?
“Well I think the biggest thing we had to do was to get the economy back on track and actually there have been 800 jobs created for every day that this government has been in office,” he says, echoing comments he first made back in 2015.
“So I know we’ve got lots of difficult things we have to do with the economy, but fundamentally today… four per cent unemployment, over two per cent annualised growth and two per cent inflation. That is a world away from the inheritance I got in 2010 when we were in real trouble. So that was the biggest thing.”
What has not gone well for the Tories, I ask him… conscious of the time.
“We’ve had the twin glaciers of Covid hitting the economy and the Ukraine war pushing up inflation. So the last two years we’ve had to spend time getting back into a strong position and that’s been painful and difficult.”
He is not wrong there is he? Painful and difficult is one way of putting it and the thing about a global pandemic is that it wasn’t in anybody’s manifesto was it? No mention of Liz Truss’ economic implosion mind.
How does he think he is going to be feeling when he wakes up next Friday morning?
“Look I don’t… I never know if these polls are right or wrong. They told me I was going to lose in 2015 and I won. This time we’re told that we’re going to do really badly but who knows?
“The only thing I do know is if you vote for Nigel Gardner here in Harpenden and Berkhamsted you’ll get a hard-working Conservative MP standing up for high streets and small towns and villages and rural areas in Parliament and if the polls are right it’ll be even more important to do so.”
He says that he has found the reception in Harpenden “pretty good, actually”, adding that if the whole country was like one particular hairdressers he’d just been into, the General Election would be a Tory landslide: “Brilliant…very friendly people!”
Unlike some of his peers, he says he has never placed a bet on himself to win or lose an election, but adds: “In 2005 when I stood for leadership of the Conservative Party there was someone who ran our party up in the north-east and he got odds on me at 66:1. Every time I went up to the north-east, which is sometimes quite a tricky area for Conservatives, as I got off the train he used to give me an enormous bear hug.”
The man won enough to take his whole family on a world cruise, he jokes. Nigel laughs. Genuinely. They’re definitely good pals.
He clarifies his views on the gambling scandal: “Obviously what’s happened is very, very wrong, and it’s right that there’s an independent investigation and also one by the Gambling Commission. If people have used inside information, that is completely wrong.”
How would he convince me to vote for Nigel then? “You should vote Blue because you’re getting a hard-working Conservative MP. He’s built businesses. You’ve got a hard-working Conservative MP who was born here, brought up here, and knows the area like the back of his hand.”
I mention that our childhood dog was called Maggie, and he laughs: “That’s a good start!”
My session with the Foreign Secretary draws to a close, with just enough time for some photos taken by local snapper Penny Bird, before David heads off with his team back to running the country.
So what did Nigel make of the experience? I caught up with him later to find out: “It was quite a surreal afternoon, taking the Foreign Secretary and former PM to pull a pint behind the bar in the pub where my granny was born upstairs!
“I saw on the High Street he has the same charm and ease with people I remember from 30 years ago – he was literally the first person I talked to at Oxford. Life moves in strange circles.”
Whether David Cameron is still Foreign Secretary come Friday remains to be seen, but none of that takes away from the rather fun experience of meeting him in Harpenden last week. Will I be voting Tory now? Well dear reader, that’s between me and my ballot paper!

Local school leaders believe up to a third of parents will withdraw their children from private schools if VAT is added to school fees. And fears are growing that this exodus will overwhelm top local state schools.
Labour has announced that it plans to immediately slap VAT on school fees if elected at the General Election which must happen before January 2025.
“Local school leaders have told me they fear Labour’s VAT hike will force up to a third of parents to withdraw their children from local independent schools, said Nigel Gardner, who was educated at Aldwickbury and then St Albans School.
“This is an ideological policy that will punish local parents who sacrifice so much to pay for their children’s education, and increase pressure on our over-subscribed top local state schools.”
Independent education is believed to be the single biggest private sector employer in the new Harpenden and Berkhamsted constituency. Concerns are also growing about the knock-on effects such an exodus will have on our local economy.
With over 600 people employed in Berkhamsted alone by private schools, the knock-on economic effects on our town will be disastrous.
“This Labour tax raid will hit swathes of local families – whether their children are at state or private schools – and damage our local economy.”

St Albans district council has been served legal papers by Harpenden Town Council relating to the controversial on-street parking charges.
SADC strategic director for community and place delivery Chris Traill has confirmed the receipt of the papers: “We have received a pre-action protocol letter from Harpenden Town Council on the new parking restrictions and have responded to it. We cannot make any further comment on such legal proceedings.”
A pre-action protocol outlines the conduct and steps parties are expected to take before commencing legal proceedings for specific types of civil claims, aiming to encourage early information exchange, settlement, and efficient case management without the need for legal proceedings.
Retailers and residents alike have opposed the measures – which were revealed by the St Albans Times last year – with an e-petition opposing the scheme signed by 1,774 people, and a further 1,264 and 6,022 signing paper and Change.org versions.
Harpenden Town Clerk Carl Cheevers previously warned that should SADC go ahead with the parking proposals, given the volume and focus of the public consultation, he believed it would be acting in potential breach of the Road Traffic Act and consultation process guidelines such as the Gunning Principles, which could lead HTC to go as far as to consider a Judicial Review.
Mr Cheevers told town councillors in November: “In this scenario, HTC may wish to instruct professional legal advice to get a view as to whether the decision has been taken through a flawed process. HTC could instruct an initial view which it would need to formally consider.
“If this view suggested that there have been issues with the process, then HTC could consider instigating further action in the form of a Judicial Review. This is a complicated and costly action to take, however it is a route open to HTC.”
The Gunning Principles are a set of four key rules established by the UK courts to ensure fairness in public consultations.
Of particular relevance to this particular process are:
* Consultation must take place when the proposal is still at a formative stage: The decision-makers must not have already made up their minds. Consultation should happen early enough in the decision-making process so that the opinions and feedback received can genuinely influence the outcome.
And:
* The product of consultation must be conscientiously taken into account: The responses received during the consultation must be given genuine consideration before any final decisions are made. Decision-makers must show they have engaged with and reflected on the feedback, even if they do not adopt all suggestions.
Council leader Cllr Paul de Kort was also unable to discuss the latest developments, and could only say: “Due to the council receiving a pre-action protocol from Harpenden Town Council, I am unable to comment.”
Harpenden Town Clerk Carl Cheevers issued a brief statement this evening: “Harpenden Town Council has previously set out its strong objection to the introduction of on-street parking charges across Harpenden Town Centre and continues to hold significant concerns regarding the impact that this will have on local businesses.
“The town council issued a pre-action protocol letter in February to SADC setting out that it is considering instigating court proceedings in the form of a Judicial Review.
“We are currently in a ‘pre-election period’ ahead of the town council by-elections on 1 May 2025. During pre-election periods, we follow statutory guidance on communications and publicity which means that we won’t be commenting on this matter any further at this stage.
“We expect to publish a detailed statement shortly after the by-elections.”
Former Conservative candidate for Harpenden, Nigel Gardner, put the parking charges at the heart of his campaign: “Hats off to our Harpenden Town Councillors.
“It’s a sad day when Harpenden has to launch legal proceedings against St Albans council and their officials. But there was simply no other way to defend our High Street traders and local community.”
“I implore St Albans council to listen, come to the table, and to compromise. If they really care about council taxpayers’ money it is the only course open to them.
“So much of this sorry saga reminds me of the ill-fated attempt by St Albans council to impose a one-way system in the late ’80s. It brought our roads and local economy to a standstill. That time councillors showed courage, accepted they had got it wrong, and did a u-turn.
“Today, the people of Harpenden and council taxpayers across the district deserve another u-turn from St Albans council officials.”

While the country waits for Rishi Sunak to stop laughing and finally set a date for this year’s General Election, pollsters are having a field day predicting the results.
Under the Dissolution and Calling of Parliament Act 2022, the power to call a General Election was restored to the Prime Minister after a period when it was at the behest of the House of Commons, but the latest a Parliament can be dissolved has to be on the fifth anniversary of the day it first met.
That means the PM actually has until December 17 to name the date, with 25 working days allowed to prepare, meaning the next General Election must be held by January 28 2025.
Asked recently when the UK would be going to the polls by a BBC local radio presenter, Mr Sunak laughed off her questions, prompting the interviewer to ask: “Why is that funny?”
There have been several major polls attempting to cast a fortune-teller’s gaze over the eventual day when we put our crosses on the ballot papers, with the result of the newly formed Harpenden and Berkhamsted constituency being particular volatile.
In January, a survey commissioned by the Conservative Britain Alliance from YouGov MRP predicted the Liberal Democrats romping to victory with 38 per cent of the vote, and the Conservatives trailing behind on 30 per cent.
But a more recent poll of 15,000 people by agency Survation on behalf of the Best for Britain campaign group said Labour was on track to win the seat with 37 per cent, the Tories on 35 per cent, and the Lib Dems only on 15 per cent.
Then no sooner had the results of the Survation survey been sampled, but YouGov was back with a detailed seat-by-seat analysis of potential results, this time giving Harpenden and Berkhamsted to the Conservatives with 34.9 per cent of the vote, compared to the Lib Dems on 24.8% and Labour on 22.1%.
Tory candidate Nigel Gardner responded: “The polls are coming in thick and fast, with two mega ones last week – each polling more than 15,000 people. The Survation poll saw Labour a few hundred votes ahead in Harpenden and Berkhamsted, whilst in the YouGov one I managed to come out on top.
“Of course the only result that matters is how the good people of Harpenden and Berkhamsted and our amazing villages vote on polling day. And between now and then I am working as hard as hard as I can to show that I will be a hard-working, responsible, common sense, local MP – who will look after the interests of all our residents whatever their politics. And to show that a Starmer Government will be bad for our economy, and a disaster for our Green Belt.”
Symon Vegro, chair of Harpenden and Berkhamsted Labour Party said: “Some polls will show us winning in the constituency, some polls will show us coming third, but the very fact that the Lib Dems are so relentless in their messaging that Labour cannot win shows how worried they are!
“If you look at the overall picture Labour is still in a strong and improving position. Even this poll – which is not consistent with other polls in recent weeks – shows that the Lib Dems – at best – are level pegging with Labour in this constituency.
“The choice at the General Election is between another five years of Conservative chaos or a decade of national renewal with Labour. The Lib Dems have no plan for government and no plan for Harpenden and Berkhamsted.
“Voters in Harpenden and Berkhamsted should not buy into the Lib Dem myth that Labour is not interested in this seat.”
Victoria Collins, Liberal Democrat Parliamentary candidate for Harpenden and Berkhamsted, also responded to the latest survey, echoing similar sentiments made by Nigel: “The only poll that matters is when voters go to the ballot box for the General Election. Across Harpenden and Berkhamsted, voters are already showing their support for the Liberal Democrats with incredible local election success. We now have 80 per cent of the councillors right across the seat from Tring, Berkhamsted and Harpenden to Redbourn, Wheathampstead and Jersey Farm.
“The fact that local MPs, such as Bim Afolami, have run off to stand in other areas, reflects how the Conservatives know this is no longer a safe seat. The Liberal Democrats, on the other hand, are working hard for local people day-in day-out to give them an MP who actually stands up for them.”
For current Hitchin and Harpenden MP Bim Afolami, the future looks even more grim, with calls for the Tory grassroots to deselect him before any General Election. The publication Conservative Post has drawn up a list of 10 current Tory MPs who it feels are not “conservative” enough, with Mr Afolami at the very top.
Mr Afolami’s office was contacted for comment on this story but failed to respond.

Ahead of a heavily-publicised visit to Chesham, the Prime Minister took time out of his busy schedule to give his backing to Harpenden and Berkhamsted Conservative Parliamentary candidate Nigel Gardner.
Rishi Sunak made the most of the May bank holiday sunshine to take a stroll through the new constituency and meet with supporters in the High Street.
Nigel said: “It was wonderful to have the PM join me for that most British of bank holiday traditions – a visit to Woods garden centre – before we hit the High Street for cakes at Daisy and Co.
“Walking down the High Street we met with lots of local residents keen for a selfie with Rishi – most of whom promised to vote Conservative in the forthcoming General Election!”

Mr Cleverly joined James Spencer and Nigel Gardner, Conservative candidates for the St Albans and Harpenden and Berkhamsted constituencies respectively.
The pair toured the Home Secretary around the Harpenden area and visited local businesses.
Mr Gardner said: “It was wonderful to welcome the Home Secretary to Harpenden.
“We took a stroll along the High Street and listened to both residents and business owners who are apoplectic about the councils ill thought out parking plans.
“We need to save our pensioners parking permits and make parking on the High Street as simple as possible. Otherwise our town will pay the price.”
Mr Spencer is aiming to unseat Liberal Democrat deputy leader Daisy Cooper. Ms Cooper won the seat by 6,000 votes, gaining the seat from the Tories back in 2019.
He said: “The message the Home Secretary gave to residents and business owners was clear. The choice at the next election is either a government led by Rishi Sunak or one led by Sir Keir Starmer and Angela Rayner.
“In both St Albans and Harpenden and Berkhamsted, a vote for any other party other than the Conservatives risks letting Labour in.”
While polls suggest Labour are unlikely to win in St Albans, a Liberal Democrat win in a traditionally Conservative seat would still indirectly help Sir Keir’s bid to reach number 10.
Harpenden and Berkhamsted is a new constituency, born out of the ashes of the old Hitchin and Harpenden seat following 2022’s boundary review.
Mr Gardner is seeking to become the first MP for the area, but polls suggest the Liberal Democrats to be on course to take the seat.

Deputy Prime Minister Oliver Dowden took time out from the dramas of Westminster to enjoy a kickabout in the sun with Parliamentary candidate Nigel Gardner.
The Hertsmere MP, who lives in the St Albans district, met with Harpenden and Berkhamsted Tory hopeful Nigel at the all-weather pitch used by the Wheathampstead Wanderers.
Funded by the Premier League and The Facilities Fund, Sport England and the 948 Sports Foundation, the £200,000 pitch opened in 2014 following a fundraising campaign led by then-vice chair of the parish council Annie Brewster.
Oliver followed in the footsteps of party chairman Richard Holden to become the second big-name Tory MP to lend his support to Nigel’s campaign.
Before trying and failing to score against the Wanderers’ youth team goalie, the two politicians met for a coffee and a chat at the nearby Brewhouse together with St Albans candidate James Spencer.
Back on the agenda was the issue of VAT on independent school fees, a Labour policy which Nigel says has proved surprisingly important to voters unhappy with the thought of funding the extra cost.
“It’s inconsequential in the amount of money they’re going to raise, because they’re not actually going to raise any money, they’re probably going to lose money,” Nigel explained.
“But it’s extremely consequential in what it does to people’s lives, and not just parents who struggle to send their kids to private education, also those parents who are trying to get their kids into top state schools, because it’s going to make the competition fiercer.”
Despite the very real threat posed by Liberal Democrat candidate Victoria Collins in the constituency, Oliver repeats the Tory mantra that this General Election is a fight between the Conservatives and Labour.
He said: “There’s only two people who can walk through the door of number 10 Downing Street, Keir Starmer or Rishi Sunak, and I think people need to focus their minds on that.
“I think in a seat like this, I think the evidence is clear actually that in the end people will probably have to choose between a Labour and a Conservative candidate.
“Of course people have frustrations about what’s happened over the past five years, but this isn’t about the past five years, this is about the next five years.”
As a local resident, what does he feel are the top issues for the St Albans district?
“Number one, the Green Belt. That is exactly what’s at risk in this election. If you look at Labour’s policy, they’ve got a cunning policy, which is they say, there’s all this Green Belt that people don’t actually like, so we’re going to designate it Grey Belt.
“Well what do you think they’re going to do? They’re going to designate the Green Belt as Grey Belt and they’re going to build all over it. The thing that makes this area so great is we have the best of both worlds, we’ve got lovely countryside, easy access into London, but ultimately they don’t care about areas like this. This isn’t where the roots of the Labour Party lie.
“Number two is the expansion of Luton Airport, and I know that in Nigel you’ll have a very strong candidate who’s actually going to fight against it.”
After visiting the all-weather pitch, there was just enough time to check out the site of the new Wanderers club house off Butterfield Road, which should be finished in the autumn.

2024 Tory Parliamentary candidate for Harpenden, Nigel Gardner, whose campaign was fought on opposing the charges, added: “I am furious. For the past year, Harpenden residents, Harpenden businesses and Harpenden lovers across the political spectrum have made it abundantly clear that they don’t want these parking charges.
“They are bad for our local economy, bad for our most vulnerable residents, and bad for our local community.
“These charges are being pushed through by Chris Traill, the council’s director of strategy, who lives in Leicester and has never knowingly tried to park in Harpenden. I fear they are ideologically driven as part of a war on local motorists.
“TS Eliot wrote April was the cruellest month. For Harpenden’s high street traders, Ms Traill has ensured this year the cruellest month will be February.
“I now hope that the town council – which has admirably put Harpenden’s interests above those of party – will move ahead with a Judicial Review to stop Ms Traill’s plans in their tracks.”
